They with a cool reception from the loyal people of that beautiful section of the State, and, to the honor of the town, we are pleased to learn, that only two Union flags were displayed, and they by those so bankrupt in character and morals as only to exetion pity for this last exhibition of their treasonable characters.

On the afternoon of Wednesday, General Shields's column advanced towards New-town, but were met and driven into Winchester by Col. Ash by's command.
On the same day, Gen. Jackson marched to Cedar creek, on the Valley turnpike, sixteen miles from Winchester and two from Stresburg, where he was encamped up to Thursday night.

Our informant expresses much admiration for the gallantry of Col. Ashby.
That officer has been constantly in the advance of Gen. Jackson's forces, and has displayed skill and courage highly to be commended.

Large militia reinforcements have been sent forward to Gen. Jackson from the counties of the upper Valley, which, with the noble volunteers under his command, it is hoped, will be sufficient for the protection of the remainder of that, beautiful Valley from the polinting tread of Yankee mercenaries and cut-throats.

Not the least agresable information imparied to is by Mr. Beall, is the effect into movements have had upon the spirit of the people.
Volunteering is going on with great spirit.--The call of the Governor has aroused the most inkewarm, and entire companies of the militia have surolled themselves for the war in the velunteer service.
General Garnett's brigade, almost to a man, have re-enlisted for the war, whilst Col. Burke's brighade have manifested the high spirit of patriotism which might have been expected from true men engaged in a cause so holy.
Before evacuating, Gen. Jackson succeeded in resoving all his stores, baggage, &c., so that not a dollar's worth of public property into the hands of the enemy.

div3.p: The News From North Carolina.

The news of the reverse at Newbern, N. C., which we publish this morning, was received here with regret, though no one acqualuted with the situation of affairs at that point could have been surprised at the result.
A small land force, without adequate fortifications, could not be expected to hold out against an imments first of gunboats, accompanied by a numerous army; and it is difficult to conceive why, under such circumstances, any attempt was made to oppose the landing of the enemy.
It is not our purpose, however, to comment upon a polty which has wrought some letter experience within the past few weeks.
The brutal contact of the invaders, in assalling the helpless women and children as they were fleeing for safty, will not be apt to exalt the Yankes character much in the eyes of civilized nations; nor do we conetive that the occupation of Newbern gives them any real advantage, except in the depredations they may and doubtless will make upon private property in the vicinity.
At present, we see no cases for discouragement grewing out of the transection.

div3.head: Operations of the enemy.
div3.p:
We learn that in Jefferson county the enemy are ruling with an iron rod. It is stated that a few days after they got possession of the county, they called upon Joseph Crane, Esq., the Sheriff, and demanded of him the county's quota of revenue for the despicable Pierpoint Government.
The Sheriff informed them that he had paid in the revenue of the county to the State of Virginia, at Richmond, when he was told that his own and the property of his securities should be sold is raise the amount.

Is Charlestown, they had destroyed the printing material in the offices of the Virginia free fress and Independent Democrat and are using the material of the Spirit of Jefferson in publishing a paper.
They have arrested a number of the citizens of the county, and have rent some of them to Fort Warren.

div3.head: The proper spirit.
div3.p:
Under the recent proclamation of Govenor Latcher, calling out the millitia of the State, the commandants of the regiment composed of the militia force of Appomattox county, numbering some 75 men liable to duty, were criered out, when, upon an examination of the muster rolls, it was found that there was but fifty-three who had not volunteered for the war. This is the spirit with which the people of Southern Virginia are rallying to the defence of their homes, and the hope may be reasonably entertained that a few weeks will witness in the field, and ready for action, an invincible host of the tried and tree men of the ancient Common wealth.
This spirit is not confined alone to the South and East, but a similar response comes up from the Valley and the West.

div3.head: The Amended Constitution
div3.p: --The returns, so far as received, indicate that the Amended Constitution of Virginia, and the clause re ring the payment of a poll tax as a constitution of suffrage, have been carried by a ority.

div3.head: Fernandina.
div3.p:
The public have felt some interest in further intelligencs from this Florida town.
The last heard from it was through a flurried telegraph, which represented that two thousand Confederates there were about to bag three thousand Federals ! Such an achievement would compensate for the abandonment of the fortifications below the town.
But the telegrapher has not yet finished the job ! Can't he hurry it up !

div3.head: Judge Arthur F. Hopkins.
div3.p:
This gentleman, who has been patriotically engaged for months past in providing for the sick soldiers in this city, was, by some strange mistake, represented in our local columns on the 14th inst, as having been committed to jail for want of security to keep the peace in the matter of an assault upon one C. Ellett.
The thing, we learn, is simply ridiculous. --Ellett preferred before the Mayor a charge against the Judge for an assault, but failed to appear before the Mayor to prosecute it, and the Judge was discharged.
We are sorry that such a mistake should have occurred.

div3.head: Table of distances.
div3.p:
Mr. James B. Ward, an officer in the Paymaster's Department, has prepared a very useful table of distances between principal points in the Confederacy.
It has been published very neatly by A. Morris, and is for sale by him. This table has been adopted by the Quartermaster's and Paymaster's Departments.
Its official character, therefore, gives it consideration, and it will prove valuable to all classes of the business community, and especially to merchants and others having extensive correspondence.

div3.head: The Exemption bill.
div3.p:
We publish this morning the Exemption Bill, adopted by the Legislature on the 14th, and invite attention to its provisions.
Those interested will observe that nothing in this last bill "shall be construed to apply to interiere with, hinder or delay the draft, under the act of February 10, 1862, to raise the quota of Virginia for the Confederate army, or to impair the effect of the act of February 18, 1862, or any acts amendatory thereof in relation to exempts."

div3.head: Cottse and tobacco.
div3.p:
--Brig. Gen. Gatlin, of the Department of North Carolina, has just issued an order, by direction of the Secretary of War, requiring that all cotton, tobacco, and naval stores, within that department, shall be removed west of the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad; or, if distant from any railroad or navigable stream, put in such places of security that they cannot be reached by the enemy.
Such of the above mentioned products as are in exposed positions, must be removed at once, and those less exposed, removed or secured by the 5th inst.; otherwise they will be destroyed by the military authorities.
The General expresses a hope that the owners themselves will apply the torch rather than see the enemy gain possession of these much-coveted products.

The fortifications near Fernandina, so much complimented by the Federal commander, were designed and superintended by Lieutenant Webb, of the Navy, recently appointed Captain in the Confederate Navy for gallant conduct in the late fight led by the Virginia.
These defensive works had received very high commendation from some of the best officers of our army.

div3.head: From Cumberland Gap.
div3.p: --The Lynchburg Republican, of yesterday, says:

q.p: On the letter bill received here Saturday evening from Cumberland Gap, dated the 12th, the postmaster at that place writes that the enemy was then in sight, and that a fight was expected the next day, (the 13th,) Thursday last.

It is the design of the enemy, doubtless, to make a powerful effort to get possession of Cumberland Gap, and thence make an advance into East Tennesses, towards Knoxville.
There was a rumor in the city yesterday of a fight, but we could trace it to noreliable source.

div3.head: Yankee prisoners.
div3.p:
--The Fredericksburg Fress, of Saturday, says that two Federal prisoners were captured a few days since, near Dumfries, by a squad of Caroline Light Dragoons, under Sergt. Wade--John Gregg, of New York, a telegraphic operator, and Lient, Baum, of Philadelphia, of General Hooker's Staff.
He had sent 300 men over, and these two had gone "on to Richmond" earlier than they expected.
The New Orleans banks supplied, in exchange for notes, the volunteers who recently left that city for the seat of war with all the silver change they wanted, taking the currency at par.

Walker's Battery paid its respects to a parcel of Federal tugs which appeared off Aquis creek last Friday.
Two shells burst on their decks, and we hope damaged them.
A Tennessecan named Crockett was hailed by the Provost Guard, in Fredericksburg, on Thursday night. Having no furlough, he raft, was fired on and killed.
All the railroads in Georgia have determined not to receive any liquors for transportation, in accordance with Governor Brown's request.
Gen. Sam Houston was in the town of Houston, Texas, on the 27th February, nearly recovered from his recent illness.
The ladies of Angusta, Ga., and vicinity, are contributing with extensive liberality to the gunboat fund.
W. W. Fosdick, a professional post, died in Cincinnati, on the 8th inst.
The last of the Audubon's died recently at Audubon Park, in New York.
Punch calls Lovejoy (U. S. Congressman) Lovejaw

argument.p: the Attach upon Newbern — the town shelled by the Yankees--Panio and Flight of the inhabitants, &c.

div4.p:
--Last night about twenty thousand Federals landed with artillery and cavalry near our batteries, a short distance from Newbern, and began skirmishing with their infantry.
The enemy's gunboats, about fifty in number, hauled up within gentlemanly distance of our batteries, and opened upon them with eight inch shell.
The fight then became general.
They drove our men from the battery.
Latham's battery was cut all to pleces.

Lieutenant-Colonel Haywood is reported killed.
He was shot in the forehead.
Colonel Campbell is wounds.

Several other officers are killed and wounded.
Many of our men were also killed, wounded, and made prisoners, but everything is in such litter disorder that nothing definite or certain can be learned.
The Federal gunboats ran up to Newbern near the Nouce river bridge and out off the retreat of most of the Confederates.

At ten o'clock this i rning about 700 militiamen who had escaped over the bridge before the Yankee gunboats got there came into Newbern at a double-quick.
Immediately after the Yankees began to shell Newbern.--Two little steamers going up the river, loaded with women and children, unable to find room in the cars, were fired upon with shot and shell by the Yankee gunboats.

At eleven A. M., the town of Newbern was on fire in two places.
It was shelled without a moment's notics.
The scene of consterna tiok and confusion was dreadful.
Women and children were running in every direction to get out of the shower of missiles, which fortunately flew wide of the town and burnt beyonp its limits.

We had about 7,000 men in this battle.
They fought well until they were flanked right and left by 25,000 Yankees.
We repulsed them several times with the bayonet, but, being surrounded by the overwhelming odds, numbers retrested in great confusion.
This is reliable.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch.]
div4.p:
--Passengers from Newbern and Goldsbore' make conflicting statements of our loss at Newbere.
It is impossible to give particulars.
All that is known is that Newbern was taken on Friday and the town set on are by the citizens, burning naval stores and cotton.
The Yankees put the fire out.
Our loss is unknown.

The Yankees are reported to have landed 25,000.
A prisoner taken, who is now in Kinstrie jail, is reported to have said that Burnside's whole force is ,000, and is distributed at Hatteras, Roan ke Island, and Newbern.

Everything is in such confusion at Goldsboro' and below that place that it will take several days to collect any definite particulars.
Some say our loss in prisoners does o exceed 500, and 250 to 300 killed and wounded. Many no doubt escaped that were supposed lost.
Several arrived here to-day on the cars.

div3.head: From the Southern coast.
div3.p:
--The Savannah News, of this morning, learns from reliable sources that two thousand Federals occupied Jacksonville, Florida, on Tuesday last, and are now throwing up breastworks and entrenchments, and have thrown out pickets two or three miles in advance of this position.
They captured four eavy guns near the city.
The Republican further learns that the Mayor of Jacksonville had issued a proclamation urging the people to remain quietly in their houses.
Steam mills and lumber mills and the foundry, together with one of our gunboats, were burned by the citizens.
The Mayor made his escape.
[This news is confirmed in part by private dispatches received here last night.-- Reporter.]

div3.head: The enemy in sight of Cumberland Gap.
div3.p: Lynchburg, Va., March 15 --The postmaster at Cumberland Gap writes to the Lynchburg Republican that, on the 13th, the enemy was in sight of that place, and that a fight was expected next day.

div3.head: Resolutions Concerning Exempts, under the proclamation of the Governor, of the 10th of March, 1862.

list.head: [adopted March 14, 1862.]
list.item: Resolved, by the General Assembly, That it shall be the duty of the Boards of Exemptions, acting under the act of February 18, 1862, and any acts amendatory thereof, to take cognizance of all cases of exemption arising under these resolutions; and that the Governor shall cause one or more Boards, with similar powers, to be organized at the several places of rendezvous indicated by his proclamation of the 10th inst., by the Commanding Officer thereof, to be composed of such persons as such Commanding Officer may designate.

2d.
That the following persons shall be exempt under the said Proclamation, to wit: all officers and employees of any railroad, canal, steamboat, or telegraph company, whose services the President and Superintendent of such company, or either of them, shall certify on honor to be indispensable for conducting the operations thereof; also, such clerks as the Quartermaster-General and Paymaster-General of Virginia shall certify on honor to be necessary to conduct the business of their respective Departments; and all superintendents and operatives in the paper mills of this Commonwealth; also, all persons whose services may be deemed by the Board of Exemptions to be indispensable in mining or manufacturing lead, iron, coal, salt, oakum, saltpetre, gunpowder, firearms, or other implements or munitions of war; also, all employees in woolen and cotton mills and incorporated shoe factories, the proprietors of which are under contracts to do work for the State or Confederate Government; and all tanners and shoemakers having contracts to do work for the State and Confederate Government as long as necessary to complete such contracts; also such officers of the several Banks of circulation in this Commonwealth, and their branches, as the respective Presidents or Cashiers may certify on honor to be indispensable to the proper management of the business of the Banks, and may be so deemed by the said Board of Exemptions; also, overseers of committees of insane persons, and such millers, blacksmiths and tanners as the said Board shall deem indispensable to the comfort of the community in which they may live, or who shall be in the employment of the State or Confederate government; also, one eiditor of each newspaper now being published, and such employees as the editor or proprietor may certify on honor to be indispensable for conducting the publication of his newspaper, so long as the same is regularly published at least once a week; also, the jailor of every city, and such guard as the Hustings Court thereof may certify to be indispensable to the safe custody of prisoners, and the jailor of Henrico county and such guard as the County court thereof may certify to be indispensable to the safe custody of prisoners.

3d.
In each apothecary store now established and doing business, one apothecary in good standing, who is a practical druggist, shall be exempt; also, the public printer, and the printer for the State Senate, and such employees as each may certify, on honor, to be indispensable for the efficient performance of the public printing; also, one deputy sheriff for every twelve thousand inhabitants of every county: Provided; however, that every county having less than twelve thousand inhabitants shall have one deputy sheriff; and one deputy of every clerk of a court who may be deemed by the Board Incompetent, by reason of physical or mental disability, to dicharge the duties of his office, or who may be absent therefrom in the public service.

4th.
It shall be competent for the Board of Exemption, whenever in their judgment it may be indispensable for the police and convenience of the community, to exempt from the performance of military duty, under the Proclamation aforesaid, overseers on the farms of widows and orphans who have heretofore contracted for that service for the present year.

5th.
That the Professors of the University of Virginia and other incorporated Colleges are hereby declared to be exempt under the said Proclamation.

6th.
Whenever, by these resolutions, any class of employees or operatives are entitled to exemption on the certificate of other persons, it shall not be necessary for the applicants to appear in person before the Board, but the exemption shall be ordered by the Board on the production of the certificate alone.

7. That persons claiming exemption under these resolutions, shall be entitled thereto so long only as the militia called out by the Proclamation aforesaid may remain in service, and while such exempts remain in the employment by reason of which such exemption was allowed.

8. Nothing in these resolutions shall be construced to apply to, interfere with, hinder or delay the draft, under the act of February 10th, 1862, to raise the quota of Virginia to the Confederate Army, or to impair the effect of the act of February 18th, 1862, or any acts amendatory thereof, in relation to exempts.

div3.head: An act to prevent the unnecessary Consumption of grain by Distillers and other Manufacturers of Spirituous and Maltliquors.--[passed March 12, 1862.

list.head: [published by order of the House of Delegates.]
list.item: 1. Be it enacted by the General Assembly, That it shall not be lawful for any person hereafter to make, or cause to be made, any whiskey or other spirituous or malt liquors, out of any corn, wheat, rye, or other grain, and any person so offending shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined for every offence, not less than one hundred dollars, nor more than five thousand dollars; and be subject to imprisonment in the county jail not exceeding twelve months at the discretion of the court.

2. Be it futher enacted, That every day which any distillery or any other machine, implement or structure, for the manufacture of spirits shall, in violation of the foregoing section, be in operation, shall be taken and held to be a separate offence within the meaning of this act.

3. Be it further enacted, That, in addition to the penalty prescribed by the first section of this act for a violation of these provisions, the distillery or other machine and implements used therewith for the purpose of making liquor, in violation of this act, shall be forfeited to the Commonwealth; and it shall be the duty of the court, in pronouncing judgment upon any conviction under this act, to add the judgment of forfeiture, and to order the sheriff to make sale of such distillery, or other machine and implements, by such execution as issues by the Commonwealth in other cases.
And it shall be the duty of the sheriff to pay the proceeds of such sale into the treasury of the Commonwealth, after deducting to himself five per cent. commission.

4. Be it futher enacted, That, as soon as any person may be presented or indicted for any violation of the previsions of this act, the court of any county or corporation, in which said proceedings is had, shall immediately issue an order to the sergeant or sheriff of such county or corporation, directing him, unless within ten days thereafter the defendant shall enter into bond, with sufficient security, in the penalty of one thousand dollars, conditioned to answer the judgment of the court, and also to have forthcoming, when required by any law, any property alleged to be forfeited under this act, then at once to seize and take possession of the spirituous or malt liquors, grain, distilling machine, and other implements used or employed in making liquor in violation of this act, and the grain, the distilling of which is hereby prohibited, and hold the same subject to the judgment of said court as herein provided.

5. And be it futher enacted, That all corn, wheat, or other grain, purchased or obtained for the manufacture of liquor in violation of the provisions of the first section or this act, shall be forfeited to the Commonwealth.--And it shall be the duty of all sheriffs, constables, commissioners of the revenue, and other officers of the Commonwealth, to make diligentinquiry into all violations of this act, and report the same promptly to the Attorney of the Commonwealth, or any justice of the peace in the county in which the offence may be committed.
If any officer shall fail to perform the duties required of him by this act, he shall be flued, at the discretion of the jury; for each neglect or failure, not less than ten nor more than five hundred dollars.

6. And be it futher enacted, After such presentment shall have been made, if the defendant should continue to operate his distillery, it shall be the duty of the sheriff or sergeant to seize and take possession of the grain, distillery, and liquors, unless he shall enter into bond in the penalty of one thousand dollars with the clerk of the court into which said presentment is depending; conditioned that he will cease the distillation of corn, wheat, rye, or other grain.
All prosecutions under this act shall be tried at the first term of the court in which they may be instituted, unless good cause be shown for a continuance.

div3.p: This act shall be in force within ten days from and after its passage, and continue in operation during the present war.
A copy from the Rolls.
Tests: Wm. F. Gordon, Jr.,
C. H. D. and K. or R. of Va.

div3.head:
Attention!
Second military class !
div3.p:
In pursuance of the Proclamation of the Governor of Virginia of the 18th March, calling out a special force from certain cities and corporations, for the defence of the State "all the white male inhabitants of the city of Richmond who reside in and around it, within one mile of the cerporation line, on the north side of James river," and who are between the ages of sixteen and eighteen and forty-five and fifty-five years, except such as are exempt by law from all military duty, are required to assemble for enrollment and organization as the military of the second class, at the times and places hereinafter mentioned.
It is hoped that all will cheerfully and promptly respond to this call, that a large and offective reserve corps may be speedily organized.
The young men will be formed into companies separate from the older men, and each company will elect its own officers.--Young men under sixteen, able to bear arms, will be admitted into the ranks.
All the youth of this character in the district are earnestly invited to come forward and prepare themselves for the service of their country.
The Commissioners of the revenue for the city and county will meet at the places appointed in their respective districts, to aid in the enrollment.

All persons embraced in this call, residing in the city, west of 7th street and one mile beyond the corporate limits west of 7th street extended north, will assemble at the Second Vegetable Market, at 8 o'clock P. M. on Tuesday, March 18th, 186 enrollment.

All residing between 7th and 14th streets, and one mile beyond the corporate limits, between the line of these streets extended north, will atsemble in front of the Hall, on Capitol street, on Wednesday, March 19th, 1862, at 8 o'clock P. M.

All residing east of 14th street and one mile beyond the corporate limits east of 14th stextended north, will assemble in Military Hall, over First Market, on Thursday, March 20, 1862, at 8 o'clock P. M.
div3.closer:
By order of the Governor.
H. K. Ellyson,
Sheriff of the City of Richmond.
mh 17--4t

div3.head:
Headq's Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 15, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 8.

I. The practice of fast driving and riding through the city endangers the safety of the people, and is, therefore, prohibited.
The speed for omulbuses, light carrlages, and horseback riding, is at the rate of five miles per hour; wagous, carts, and other vehicles for freight, will be driven at a walk, whether loaded or unloaded.
The police and patrol are charged with the execution of this order, and will arrest every one who may violate it, no matter what his rank or position.
If the driver or rider be a v hite man, he will be confined and brought before a court-martial; if a negro, he will immediately receive, for the first offence, 39 lashes; for the second and every succeeding offence, 50 lashes.
div3.closer:
John H. Winder,
Brig. Gen. Commanding, &c. mh 17--1w

div3.head:
33 Dregiment Henrico militia.
Attention.
div3.p: --All persons in my company district, between the ages of 18 and 45 years, are hereby notified to meet at Buchanan Spring, on Monday, the 17th inst., at 11 o'clock A. M., with all the arms they can procure, and two blankets, &c., and at 12 o'clock will march to the encampment, at the new Fair Grounds.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. Lyons.
Henry Younger, Captain.
The bounds are as follows: Outside of corporation line, and on the north side of Broad street, to Brook creek, and thence to Brook turnpike, on the west side to the corporation line. mh 17 --1t

div3.head: Heavy Artillery.
div3.p: $50 Bounty, and Uniforms furnished.

The unders gued are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company for the heavy Artillery service.
We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutsnants of such a company, and have already a number of men enliated.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, up stairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.
div3.closer:
Thomas G. Jackson.
mh 17--1m Thomas Lawson.

div3.head: Heavy Artillery.
div3.p: I am authorized by the Secretary of War to raice a battalion of Heavy Artillery for the defence of James river. One more company wanted to complete the battalion — If offered at once will be received — at Jamestown Island.
mh 17--1w Wm. Allan, Capt.

div3.head:
Attention !
Parker Battery.
div3.p:
Assemble promatly at 10 o'clock A. M, on Monday, the 17th, at Old Market Hall, in order to march to the camp of instruction--Each man will bring with him a shawl or blanket, a large tin cup and tin plate with cocked provisions for one day. Overcoats.
caps, and one blanket each, will be issued to the men. None but a written permit will exempt from this muster.
div3.closer:
By order of
mh 17--1t Captain Parker.

div3.head:
Attention !
Wise Mounted Guard.
div3.p: All members of this company will report themselves at camp, Howard's Grove, on Tuesday morning at 10 o'clock. Every member is requested to be punctual in attendance, as election of officers will be held.
div3.closer:
Lieut. L. J. Hawley,
mh 17--2t Wise Legion.

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p: Members of Capt Josep W. Barlow's Company, forming a part of Allan's Battalion, are ordered to report at headquarters this (Monday) morning, at 10 o'clock promptly.
div3.closer:
By order of the Captain.
mh 17--1t Chas. E. Scherer, O. S.

div3.head: Mmilitary notice
div3.p: --Members of the Otey Battery will report Wednesday, for duty at the company Headquarters, No. 12 Pearl street. Members in the country will come prepared to go into camp.
div3.closer:
By order.
mh 17--8t G. G. Otey, Captain.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Crutchfield Light Artillery,
March 18th, 1862.
attention, Volunteers !
Battery secured.
div3.p:
The undersigned, having secured a splendid Battery of field-pleces, have authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be ountered in the Provisional Army of Virginia for the war, and have received authority from the Governor to recruit volunteers from the militia, to fill the ranks of the Crutebfield Light Artillary.
The company will be mustered in as soon as a sufficient number of volunteers have been received.
A fine opportunity now presents itself to those who do not wish to go as militiamen, to enroll themselves as volunteers,. No substitutes received.
Apply at the office of the Old Dominion Insurance Company under the St. Charles Hotel.
div3.closer:
Stapleton Crutchfield,
Chas. H. Wo Am.
mh 13--ts(if)

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 64, page 4.

div3.head: Improvised Generals.
div3.byline: [For a forthcoming number of Dr. Bun's Revise]

div4.head: By George
div4.p:
Intelligent reader, if you were required to make a pair of negro's brogans, would you not reply that you could not make them, because you never learned the shoemaker's trade?
Supposing you to be honest, patriotic, intelligent, over fifty years of age, and wholly unacquainted with the practice or science of military matters, and you were offered an appointment as Captain, or Colonel, or General in the Confederats army, with a salary of one, two, or three thousand dollars per annum, would you not unhesitatingly reply, "I know nothing of the art of war; am too old to learn, and will not, for the sake of fifthy lucre, betray my country !" "Appoint somebody also who has learned military affairs, either at school or in camp." Are stump orators Gods; born like Minerva, Bellona, or Mars, full armed, all- wise and invincible chieftains; and you, my intelligent readers, made of different and of baser clay, can you conceive it possible for a mere mortal, past fifty, to become a good soldier or a great General, without previous study, or practice, or experience?
Cartainly not. If a single one of our improvised officers makes a good leader from the start, he must be like Joan of Are, inspired from above.
But the day of miracles and of impiration has passed, and we are doomed to frequent reverses and defeats, until our young stump-crater officers have learned the art of war, and the old ones are sloughed off.

The war will last so long as mere demagogues occupy high places, either in civil life or in the army.
When we get rid of them, we shall see light ahead, and feel hope reviving.
We shall, in the meantime, learn a useful lesson, gain valuable experience, yet pay most dearly for it. But peace breeds demagogues, as surely as chesse breeds maggots; and if this war be succeeded by a long interval of peace, a new brood of stump crators will grow up out of the rottenness and corruption of pacific times.

We were much offended at hearing a distinguished officer, when the war had just begun, lamenting the enthusiasm and inconsiderateness with which our people entered into it. We now see, and feel, that he was right.
Our furor and enthusiasm clouded our judgments, made us overrate ourselves and underrats our enemies, and begat remireness and rashness.
No doubt, at the time of their appointment, our stump crators believed themselves quite a match for Yankees, and probably our intelligent readers then concurred in the opinion.
They and the public, since passion has cooled, and judgment and reason resumed their away, have learned better.
Our armies will soon be filled with new levies, whilst those opposed to us have been subjected for many months to excellent drill and discipline.--We must not have ignorant and inexperienced officers to command, train and discipline ignorant and inexperienced troops.

div3.head:
War Department,
Adj't and Insp'r Gen.'s office,
Richmond, March 14, 1862.

list.head: General Orders, no. 15.
list.item:
I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:
proclamation.
By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that Martial Law is hereby extended over the counties of Elizabeth City, York, warwick, Gloucester, and Mathews; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that enabling the courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the extates of deceased persons, the qualifications of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and to order thepayment of county dues,) and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in the counties aforesaid.
In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal, this fourteenth day of March, in the yearone thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.
Jefferson Davis.

II. Major-General Magruder, commanding the Army of the Peninsula, is charged with the due execution of the foregoing Prodismation.
He will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders:
All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forth with be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a Court-Martial; provided, that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.

div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
[Signed] S. Cooper,
mh 15--1w Adj't and Insp. General.

list.head: General Orders, no. 11.--
list.item:
I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:
proclamation.
By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in cities threatened with invasion--
I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that Martial law is hereby extended over the city of Petersburg and the adjoining and surrounding country ot the distance of ten miles, and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that of the Mayor of the city, and that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualifications of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus within the said city and surrounding country to the distance aforesaid.
In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal, on the eighth day of March, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.
(Signed,) Jefferson Davis.

II. William Pannill is appointed Provost Marshal, and is charged with the due execution of the foregoing Proclamation, and will enforce the following orders:
"All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed."

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a Court-Martial, provided that no sentence to hard labor for more than one mouth shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.

div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
(Signed,) S. Cooper,
mh 11--1w Adjt. and Insp'r Gen.

div3.head: The Virginia Battery.
div3.p:
--This company has been received by the Governor of the State, and a Battery of six pieces of Light Antillery secured.
It is the object of those who are already members to make its complement 130 men, and to admit none but gentleman, who would be pleasant associates under any circumstances.
We have already a number from the University company, which served under Gen. Wise in Western Virginia, and some who were at the University during the past session, but who promptly left the ease and comfort of that institution, after our recent reverses, to share the fate of their fellow-citizens in attempting to achieve Southern independance.
The other members of the company, we are safe in saying, will accept no other characteristics but those of gentlemen.
We cordially invite any who may wish to unite themselves with such a company to report immediately to either of the officers in Charlettesville, where the proper authorities allow them to remain until they are thoroughly organized and uniformed.
The officers are:
div3.closer:
Captain James McD. Carrington,
1st Lt. James Dinwiddie,
2d Lt John H. Timberlake.
3d Lt. A. B. Cochran,
4th Lt. A. B. Cochran, mh 15--3t*

div3.head: Thirty-Third Regiment--attention, militia.
div3.p:
--According to the Governor's proclamation, and an order from Colonel Lyons, I hereby notify all persons between the ages of 18 and 45 years, within the following bounds, to meet at Buchanan Spring, on Monday, the 17th of the present month.
The bounds are as follows: Commencing on Broad street, outside the corporation line, runs up to Brook creek; thence to Brook Turnpike, to the corporation line; thence to Broad street. The men will bring two blankets, &c., with them
div3.closer: mh 15--2t* Cpt. Henry Younger.

div3.head: Richmond Flying Artillery.
div3.p:
--I will receive substitutes from the country of ages from 16 to 18 years. They will serve as such until they arrive at the age of 18 years, respectively.
Other substitutes will also be received.
Office opposite Law Building, Franklin street, Richmond.
div3.closer: mh 15--2t* Thos T. Cropper.

div3.head:
Headq's 46th Reg. Va. Vols.,
First Infantry, Wise Legion,
near Richmond, March 1862.
div3.p: Special order No.--

All officers, non-commissioned officers, and privates, not on parole, belonging to this command, will report for duty immediately at Camp Wise, near Richmond, otherwise they will be considered as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of Col. J. H. Richardson,
Commanding,
John M. Page, Acting Adjutant.
mh 14--2t*

div3.head:
War Department,
Adj't and Insp'r Gen'soffice,
Richmond, March 13, 1862.
div3.p: Genral Orders, No. 14.
General Robert E. Lee is assigned to duty at the seat of Government; and unper the direction of the Presidentals charged with the conduct of military operations in the armies of the Confederacy.
div3.closer:
By order of the Secretary of War.
[Signed] S. Cooper,
mh 14--1w Adj't and Insp'r Gen'l.

div3.head: Magruder Light Artillery.
div3.p: Organized by order of the Secretary of War, and commanded by Officers of Gneral Marguder's Staff.
Battery of Rifled pieces and Howitzers, with the best equipments already secured.
$50 Bounty, and Transportation furnished at once.

This Battery, which will for the present be stationed on the Peninsula, needs a few more Recruits to complete its organization; and as extraordinary inducements are presented by this company to those desirous of enlisting in Light Artillery, (the most popular arm of the service,) immediate application should be made to
div3.closer:
Stephen, D. Yancey,
No. 7. Wall st., under St. Charles Hotel.
Or to Lieut. T. J. Page,
Hdqrs. Army of Peninsula; Yorktown.
mh 14--8t*

div3.head:
Attention, Artillery!
thirty Recruits
wanted.
div3.p:
We are authorised by the Governor to raise a Company of Artillery, Apply to Colonel S. T. Bayly, at the office of Bayly & White, Richmond; Col. Wm. R. Wdin, Ashland, and to Sergeant J. A. Williams, Recruiting Officer, Chesterfield.
We have authority to enlist militiamen until they are mustered into actual service.
div3.closer:
Samuel T. Bayly,
Capt. Co. "A," 20th Reg't Va. Vols.
Wm. R. Winn,
mh 14--6t* Col. 76th Reg't Va. Militia.

div3.head: Attention, citizen Sondiers!
div3.p: Fifty or Sixty
able Bodied men, wanted.

The undersigned having had considerable military experience, and recently attached to the Wise Legion as Captain of Artillery, desiren to organise another similar company for immediate service in the Confederate States service.
Each man will be paid Fifty Dollars (bounty money when enlisted, and have his uniform furnished.
Now is the time to raily for the defence of our country against the base Yankee invaders.
Headquarters on 10th, between Main and Cary streets. 27--3w*) James Kirry.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Lients. Robert C. Nicholas, Jr., and James H. Pearch, will receive Recruits for the War for Capt. G. A. Wallace's Company, the "Richmend Light Guard,' which company was engaged in the battle on Hoaneke Island, twenty men only having escaped being made pritoners.
Although, patriots need no such inducement as county money yet it is well known that a bonus of $50, and $25 commutation for clothing is given to each recruit.
Apply immediately at the office over the store of Wm. H. Tyler, on 13th street, between Main and Cary, mh 13--3t

div3.head: Having
div3.p: received authority from the Secretary of War to raise an independent battalion of Light Infantry, to be used exclusively as skirmishers and scouts, and to be attached to no other corps, except at the discretion of the Commander-in-Chief of the department in which we may be stationed, in times of great emergency, I call for volunteers from my own and other States--men now in service, or who have not yet enlisted — to come forward at this critical juncture, when the primal glory of our arms is partially ecilpsed in a temporary gloom, and enroll their names in a corps which will come frequently in contact with the polluters of our soll and the desolators of our homes.

I propose to facilitate the organization of the battalion by offering Captaincies to those enlisting not less than thirty men, 1st Lieutenancies to those enlisting twenty-five, 2nd do, to those enlisting twenty.
Seventy privates will be the minimum for a company.
The usual bounty will, of course, be paid, and subsistence and transportation furnished.
For particulars, address me at Yorktown, or W. H. Scott, Druggist, Richmond, Va.
div3.closer:
Chas. H. Causey,
mh 11--2w Lieut. Cavalry, C. S. A.

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p:
--The organization of our company is now nearly completed.
We have the guns secured and all equipments ready as soon as we are mustered into service.
Those who do not immediately volunteer will be obliged to go into the militia service.
The system of substitution has been ahandoned by the Government, so that all who are bound for service must now represent themselves in person, This we announce upon authority.
We then earnestly invoke those who are willing to share with us the fortunes of this war, who would rather appear voluntarily upon the field in defence of their country than be the reluctant soldiers of coerclon, to come forward now, this day, and enlist their names as volunteers in a great and glorious cause.
Apply at our office in the Whig Building.
div3.closer:
Marmaduke Johnson,
John W. Bransford,
A. B. Guigon,
mh 11--ts V. J. Clutter.

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
--The Infantry Company organized at the office of Dr. Parker, in the Law Building, having received assurance of a "Battery of Light Artillery," it was unanimously resolved, at a meeting held last Saturday night, to adopt that arm of the service.
The guns will be ready in less thirty days. So soon as the company is fully organized it will go into the Camp of Instruction at the Fair Grounds.
All those disposed to join will report as early as possible, at Dr. Parker's office, as the company expects to be mustered in this week.
Meetings held regularly on Wednesday and Saturday nights.
mh 11--ts

div3.head: Having
div3.p: been authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Battalion or a Regiment of Heavy Artillery, for three years or the war, I should be glad to confer with Captains who have companies not yet mustered into the service, and also those who desire to raise companies.

Volunteers or recruits enlisting for three years will receive a bounty of $50, payable as soon as they are sworn into service and accepted, upon inspection, by a medical officer, together with transportation and subsistence, from the time and place of enlistment, until inspected and mustered.

Twelve months men can re-enlist, singly or by companies.
for two years or the war, and receive $50 bounty.
To those citizens who have not reported themselves, as required, and who will in a few days be drafted, now is the time, and the last, to serve as volunteers.
Volunteers will be received singly or by companies, from any portion of the Confederacy.
Office under the St. Charles Hotel, Old Dominion Insurance Company, Main street. City Post- Office, Box 877.
div3.closer:
Robert F. Morriss,
Colonel 179th Regiment.
I have the promise of Armstrong field pleces; and should it be realized, this regiment will enter the field as Light Artillery.
mh 6--12t

div3.head: Light Artillery Battalion.
div3.p:
--On account of recent enactments by the Legislature, I have had to give up two of the companies I accepted for my Battalion.
I now wish two more companies--one from Virginia, the other from without the State.
Capt. S. T. Martin and Lieuts. Holliday and Garnett are recruiting a company for this command in this city.
Their office is Bank at., 2d door above 12th.

No companies need offer that will not be able to report within a short time.
The guns, I have been assured I shall receive in a short time.
div3.closer: mh 11--6t Francis J. Boggs.

div3.head:
Executive Departhent,
Richmond, Va., March 7, 1862.
div3.p:
all Sheriefs and others collecting State Arms, are desired to have the same boxed, macked "Col. C. Dimmock, Richmond, Va.," and forwarded as soon as possible.
The compensation for collecting, and the necessary expenses of transportation to this city, will be paid on the presentation of the receipts of Col. Dimmock.
div3.closer:
Approved,
John Letcher.
City papers copy. mh 7--1m

div3.p:
I Am authorized by the Secretary of War to raise an Infantry Company, and as no more new companies will be accepted until Virginia's quota has been furnished, (this company will be counted as a part of it,) this is one of the few last chances to escape the draft; and who would be drafted?
Men accepted from all parts of the State or Confederacy.
Twelve months men can reenlist with me. $50 bounty paid as soon as inspected.
Recruiting office at the office of the Insurance Company of the State of Virginia, under the American Hotel, Richmond, Va., Address me,
div3.closer: mh 10--ts W. B. Robins.

div3.head: Recruits — Richmond sharp-shooters.
div3.p:
Fifty Recruits are wanted to fill up the ranks of this well-known company to the maximum number.
A bounty of $50 will be paid each recruit, and sustenance commuted until they join the company; pay commences from date of enlistment.
None but good men need apply, as the company heretofore has susteinad an enviable reputation.

This company is armed with good Rifles, and has seen as much active service as any company in the army.
Application to be made to the undersigned at Star Exchange, Bank street, or to Corporal W. J. Wingfield.
div3.closer:
H. E. Depriest,
mh 3--1m Lieut. and Recruiting Officer.

div3.head:
Headq's Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 12, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 43.

III.
The municipal laws regulating charges for the hire of hacks, wagons, and drays, will be rigidly enforced.

All hacks, wagons, and drays will post, in some conspicucus place about their vehicles, the list of rates allowed by law, and any driver charging more than those rates, will be imprisoned, and the license withdrawn.
div3.closer:
John H. Winder,
Brig.Gen. Commanding, &c.
mh 13--6t

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillerymen.
div3.p: --All who wish to join the Henrico Light Artillery, which is fully equipped and in service on the Peninsula, will call at the Clerk's Office of Henrico Circuit Court, in the basement of the State Court-House, where they can get information in regard to the bounty of $50, &c. J. H. Sands,
div3.closer: mh 6--12t Capt. Comd'g.

div3.head: Recruits wanted
div3.p:
--$50 Bounty — And Uniforms Furnished.--The undersigned, having been duly authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a company of Heavy Artillery, to man the batteries at Yorktown, want a few more men to complete the company.
For further particulare, apply to Sergeant James McDONALD, 12th st., opposite the Enquirer office.
div3.closer:
W. N. Coffin,
Capt. of Artillery.
S. S. Nicholas,
W. P. Woodroof.
Apply at Rendenvous on Bank street, near the corner, 10th street. mh 10--6t

div3.head: Attention, young men of Richmond!
div3.p: Having been detailed to recrult for the First Regiment Virginia Volunteers, (now stationed at Centreville,) a bounty of Fifty Dollars, uniform and subsistance, will be given to all able-bodied young men who may enlist in this, the oldest volunteer regiment in the Confederate States.
For further particulars apply at the recruiting station, No. 3,10th street, between Main and Cary streets.
div3.closer:
W. W. Harrison, Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer.
P. S.--Two new companies will be received, as there are at present but eight in the regiment. [mh 3--ts] W. W. H.

div3.head: Attention
div3.p:
The undersigned propose to raise a company of Light Arililery to be enlisted for the war. We are happy now to announce that we have procured the guns, which will be ready for us, together with all equipments, as soon as our company is mustered into service.
To those who would like to go along with us and share with us the fortunes of this war, we arnestly appeal to come forward now and join us at office.
Besides the bounty of $50, uniforms, board and lodgings will be furnished free.
Application may be made at our Recruiting office, on Main, between 7th and 8th streets, or at the store of Johnston & Bransford.
div3.closer:
Marms Duke Johnson, John W. Bransford,
fe 26--ts A. B. Guigon.

div3.head:
Attention — Boggs's
Battalion Flying Artillery.
div3.p:
The undersigned having authority to raise a Company to form a part of this splendid corps, for which the most approved light Rifled Piechs are now being turned out, all those wishing to join a select company, and avoid the militia, will do well to enroll themselves at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly.
The special attention of the militia ininvited to the fact that we are authorized to give the most positive assurance that no man enlisting in this company remains liable either to the present call of the Governor, or to any future drafe upon the militia.
Who will wait to be a drafted militiaman?
Apply at Recruiting Office of the Battallon, Bank street, near corner of 12th.
Bounty down--Fifty Dollars.
We refer particularly to Major Boggs's card calling on those who wish to enter his corps, to report to the officers of this company
div3.closer:
S. Taylor Martin, 1st Company Howlizers.
Alex'r Q. Holladay, Lieut. 20th Regt. Va. Vols.
Wm. F. G. Garnett, Jr., Fayette Artillery.
Richard M. Rolling, Goochland Light Dragoous.
N. B.--None but men of good character need apply. mh 12--6t

div3.head: Attention, Volunteers.
div3.p: --It will be seen by the following proclamation that persons who prefer to volunteer rather than be subjected to the discredit of the militia draft, can do so by coming forward now and declaring their willingness to serve their country of their own accord:

div4.p:
The commandants of companies of volunteers, authorized to be raised by the Governor, which are not yet completed are hereby permitted to fill up their commands by volunteers from the militia of the State until the militia are mustered into service.
No substitutes will be allowed.
div4.closer:
By order of the Governor.
S. Bassett French, Aid de-Camp.

div4.p:
It will thus be seen that the alternative presented now is, whether Virginians will velunteer to defend the Southern cause, or be subjected into service by force.
As will be seen, this choice must be made at once.
Will not the sons of Virginia now come forward and amist their names.--Apply at our office, in the Whig Building.
div4.closer:
Marmaduke Johnson,
John W. Bransford, A. B. Guigon.
mh 12--ts V. J. Clutter.

div3.head: Richmond Encampment, no. 2, K. T.
div3.p: --The members of Richmond Encampment, No. 2, K. T., desirous of forming a military Company for city defence, under the act passed March 7th, 1862, will call at the store of Mr. J. F. Regnault, or upon either of the undersigned Committee, this Week, and enroll their names.
div3.closer:
E. H. Gill, Comitee.
W. L. Maule, Comitee.
James A. Scott, Comitee.
Charles Campbell, Comitee.
W. T. Allen, Comitee.
mh 12--4t

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 11, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 6.

list.item:
II.
Railroad companies are forbidden to transport into this city or out of it, spirituous liquors or other intoxicating beverages.

III.
Superintendents of railroads are requested to report daily to the Provost Marshal the number of passengers passing over their roads out of the city of Richmond.

div3.closer:
By order of
Brig. Gen'l Jno. H. Winder, Com. &c.
mh 13-- L. R. Page, A. A. Gen'l

div3.head:
Headq'rs Elliott Grays,
Fort Nelson, Noriolk harbor,
March--, 1862.
div3.p:
this well-known company having determined to remain in the service, is desirous of increasing the number of enlisted men to 125.
A Recruiting Office has been opened for that purpose at the store of Louis J. Bossieux, 80 Main street, and also at the store of Joseph Butler, town of Manchester.
All young men who are disposed to volunteer can learn the particulars of the condition and organization of the company from Lieut. Henry Fitzgerald, who can be found at either place of rendearous.
Recruits are entitled to pay, transportation, and subsistence, from the time and place of enrollment, and also to the bounty of fifty dollars.

I hope that this call may meet with a speedy response, and that I may never be a witness to the drafting of young men from the districts in the neighborhood of Richmond.
All rocruits are to be persons of good character, and men in whom I can place implicit confidence.
div3.closer:
Louis F. Bossieux. Captain Elliott Grays.
Henry Fitzgerald, Lieut., Recruiting. Officer.
mh 10--ts

div3.head:
Headq'rs 33d Reg. Va. Militia.,
March 11, 1862.
div3.p: the Commandants of Companies will muster the men under their command at their respective muster grounds, with the least possible delay, with all the arms under their control, and organize them for marching to the sucampmant at the New Fair Grounds, near the city of Richmond; and on Monday morning, the 17th of this month, they will march to the said encampment.
Each man will bring with him two blankets.
The Majors will see to the execution of this order in their respective battalions.
div3.closer:
By order of the Colonel.
mh 12--4t John Wickham, Adj't.

div3.p:
--Having re-organized and re-enlisted for two years, is desirous of receiving forty additional recruits, to raise the company to the number of one hundred and fifty.
The battary is composed of four brass six-pounders and two rifle guns, and is among the finest in the Confederate Army.
The Fayette Artillery is one of the best equipped companies in the service.
A liberal bounty will be given to each recruit.
Only men of respectability, courage, and patriotism, are, however, required.
For further particulars, apply to Peyton Johnston, 116 Main street, Richmond, or to the undersigned, at Yorktown.
div3.closer:
M. C. Macon,
mh 12--6t Capt. R. F. A.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The Second Company of Richmond Howitzers has been reorganized, and Lieutenant David Watson elected Captain.
We are anxious to increase the number of our Company to 120.
An opportunity is thus offered to young men of good moral character to join an old organization, which has two rifles and two howitzers, and is thoroughly equipped for field service.

Apply to R. B. Pleasants or Henry S. Jones, No. 7, Wall street, under St Charles Hotel; or Wm. N. Wellford, Jr., Brandy Station, Culpeper county, Virginia, or Geo. L. Christian, Charles City C. H., Virginia.
mh 10--14t

div3.head:
Confederate States of America,
Quartermaster's office,
Richmond, Va., 7th March, 1862.
div3.p:
to Railroads.--To facilitate the transfer of Recruits from Recruiting stations to their Regiments, officers of railroad companies are notified that the Recruiting Officers are authorized to give orders of transportation for their recruits, and such orders or certificates of transportation given by the persons in charge of the recruits, will be acknowledged as sufficient vouchers for payment.
Larkin Smith.
div3.closer: mh 8--10t Ass't Q. M. Gen.

div3.head:
Light Artillery!!
Battery secured!!!
Bounty Fifty Dollars!
div3.p:
The undersigned having secured a splendid battery of field pieces, have authority to raise a Company of Light Artillery, to be mustered into the service of the Provisional Army of Virginia.
for the war. Each man will be entitled to a bounty of $50 upon being mustered in. As an opportunity of enlisting in this arm of the service will not hereafter be of frequent occurrence, those wishing to join will make application at, once at the rendezvous, northwest corner of Cary and 11th streets, where one or more of the undersigned can always be seen.
Those having substitutes will send them in at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly.

div3.head: Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--The present condition of our country seems to us to require the services of all who are capable of bearing arms and in a situation to leave home.
We have therefore obtained from the Secretary of War authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, and call upon our fellow citizens to come forward and aid us in getting it up.

We want, if possible, to raise a company sufficient to man a battery of six guns, and think this enterprise offers a fine opportunity to all who wish to volunteer, and thus save themselves from a draft in the militia.
Gray uniform, of the Orenshaw Woolen Company Goods, will be furnished free, and the bounty of $50 paid to each man when the company is mustered in.
Rendervous at the warchouse on the Barin bank, next door to Crenshaw & Co's, where one of the undersigned may always be found, and recruits maintained free of all expense.
The traveling expenses of recruits from the country to the city will be paid.
div3.closer:
William G. Crenshaw,
James Ellett,
Charles L. Horson,
to 10--ts Andrew R. Johnston.

div3.head: Militia, attention
div3.p: --I am authorised by the Secretary of War to raise a Company of Heavy Artillery, to be attached to Morriss's Battalion.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid when the soll is signed and the volunteer sworn in.
Call at F. H. Starke's, Main, between 14th and 15th streets, for the present.
Any militiamen can come in sign the roll, take the bounts, and be exempt.
div3.closer: mh 14--13t H. W. Starks, Captals.

div3.head: Recruits wanted--
div3.p: 40 Volunteers, to fill up
the Virginia Life Guard.

Being ordered on recruiting service.
I will receive new members for the above company at my office, near Shockon Warchouse, between 10 o'clock A. M. and 2 P. M. This company was among the first in the field, and are re-culisting for the war. Acquaintances of the present members of the company who prefer being in assosiation with their friends to being drafted, will do well to volunteer at once in this company.
Substitutes will not be received.
Arms--Enfield Rifles.
The usual bounty, &c., given.
div3.closer:
Jno, Stewart Walker,
mh 10--9t Captain Virginia Life Guard.

div3.head: Naval medical Board of examination.
div3.p: --A Board of Naval Surgeons is in session in the city, by order of the Navy Department, for the examination of candidates for admission in the naval service of the Confederate States as assistant surgeous during the war.
The age of the condidate must not be fess than twenty-one nor more than thirty years.
div3.closer:
James Cornick, President.
mh 12--1w

div3.head: Twenty Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Runaway in this city, two weeks ago, my boy, Allen, he is 16 years old, slender, and rather small for his age, copper colored with nearly straight hair, small, sharp features, has rather a fine, whining voice; had on when he left a black frock coat, dark drab or lead colored pantaloons, and a military cap. He is no doubt passing for a free boy and may have left the city with soldiers, they under the belief that he was free; if so, and they should see this notice, I would take it as a great favor to inform me. I will pay the above reward for his apprehension.
My address is Richmond, Va., (Mayo's warehouse.)
mh 12--6t Jas. L. Scoggin.

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--$25 reward.--Left without provocation, about the 1st January last, my boy Henry, about 26 years of age, a barber by trade, hired for the present year to Wormer & Co., opposite the American Hotel.
Henry is a spare, brown colored boy, about 5 ½ feet high genteel address, wears a small beard, with full head of hair.
He may have hired himself to go with some officer or soldier.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me or Mr. Wermer, or any information of his whereabouts, so that I get him.
mh 14--2w M. Sizer.

div3.head:
Runaway--
$100 reward,
div3.p:
If found without, $50 if found within this State, Runaway in November last.
Jesse, a man about 24 years old. He is about 5 feet 10 or 11 inches in height, very slim and delicate looking, has been brought up as a dining room servant, has sprightly manners, is of a gingerbread color, has one ancle sprained and limps slightly, has one of his thumbs a great deal enlarged from a whitlow.
and has rather red eyes.
The above reward will be paid if he be delivered to Mr. Ed. D. Eacho, or lodged in jail in Richmond.
S. P. Flournoy.
mh 5--6t

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from the 4th Regiment Virginia Cavalry, at Camp Ewell, near Manassas, a bay Mare, six years old, star in forehead, thick set, in good order, bushy mane and tall, and one hind leg a little larger than the other.
Raise her mane and you will see where it has been trimmed underneath.
I will give the above reward to any one returning the above-described mare to me, or for any information which will enable me to get her.
Edmond Rossieux,

mh 5--12t Lieut.
Co. I 4th Va. Cav.

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p: --A negro boy by the name of Floyd, had been staying with his young master at Evansport, and was taken sick and started home with a man by the name of Dr. M. E. Herst, and the train left him at Burksvills, Va. The said boy is about 35 years of age, dark complexion, about 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high.--His general weight is about 150 pounds. Any person taking up the said boy, will have him confined in some safe jail, and I will pay all charges for his delivery to me.
J. W. Alsobrooks,
fe 17--1m Mill Town, Alabama.
